Dear parent, Please Immunize the Child before he/she is Affected
The disease mainly affect the children. The child gets it by breathing in droplets from an infected child.
Diphtheria
Prevention and Treatment
1. Diphtheria can be prevented by immunising a child with combined DPT-HepB+Hib vaccine three times before the age of 1 year. This prevents Diptheria as well as 4 other diseases.
2. Living in a well ventilated house.
3. Covering mouth when coughing to avoid spreading the disease.
How can one tell a child has Diphtheria
1. A child with Diptheria has a sore throat, mild fever, swelling of the neck, and difficulty in breathing.
2. Some children may develop weakness in one or more limbs which progresses to lameness and thinness of the affected limbs.
3. Sometimes Polio can affect the lungs and the child will stop breathing and die.
Poliomyelitis (Polio)
It is caused by a virus. Children get it by taking in water and food contaminated by faecal matter, containing the Polio virus.
Polio is a disease which is characterised by weakness of the limbs especially of the legs.
1. Polio can be prevented by immunising the child with Polio vaccine 4 times.
2. Additional doses of Polio vaccine to all children below 5 years during National Immunisation Days (NIDs) will eradicate Polio disease from your community.
3. Use of safe water, washing hands before handling food and after using the toilet or latrine.
How can one tell a child has Polio?
1. Polio is a sickness that begins with a mild cold
2. Some children may develop weakness in one or more limbs which progresses to lameness and thinness of the affected limbs.
3. Sometimes Polio can affect the lungs and the child will stop breathing and die.
Tuberculosis (TB)
This is a disease caused by a bacteria, characterised by fever, cough and weight loss. Most children get the infection from infected adults.
It is spread through air especially where one is near an infected person.
1. TB can be prevented by immunising a child with BCG vaccine at birth.
2. Proper feeding (balanced diet).
3. Children should not mix with infected people.
4. Live in well ventilated houses.
5. Cover your mouth when coughing to avoid spreading the disease.
How can one tell a child has TB?
1. A child has prolonged cough of more than 2 weeks
2. A child has no appetite and loses weight.
3. Sometimes Polio can affect the lungs and the child will stop breathing and die.
Hepatitis B (liver disease)

Hepatitis B is a serious disease of the liver and is caused by the Hepatitis B virus (HBV) which usually exists in the blood and bodily fluids of the infected person. Hepatitis B virus causes chronic infections that lead to liver damage (cirrhosis), liver cancer and death.

There is no cure for Hepatitis B Virus illnesses. Children get it through cuts, casual contact and from their mothers at birth. Hepatitis B is also spread through blood transfusions, unsafe injections, and sexual contact (adults) with an infected person.
1. Through immunising all children below one year 3 times with combined DPTHepB+Hib vaccine. Three injections prevent Hepatitis B and 4 other diseases.
2. Immunisation in childhood protects the child from Hepatitis B for at least 10 years.
How can one tell a child has Hepatitis B (Hep B)?
1. In children, no signs or symptoms are usually seen, but infected children remain infected for many years and can spread the infection to others.

2. Usually, the effects of Hepatitis B appear during adulthood as yellow skin and eyes, weight loss, vomiting and weakness.Over time, Hepatitis causes coma and death. Many people become infected with Hepatitis B during childhood, and carry the disease into adulthood.
